title: EasyJet shares slip despite cashing in on Ryanair and British Airways strikes
text:
Shares in Easyjet slid from five-month highs in early trading on Tuesday as the budget airline's fourth quarter trading update failed to meet investors' high expectations.

Easyjet said it benefited over the past few months from higher demand as strike disruption knocked two of its rivals, Ryanair and British Airways.

It delivered an 8.6 per cent surge in passenger numbers to 96million for the year and confirmed that annual profits were likely to come in at the top end of its forecast - between £420million and £430million.

EasyJet said it benefited over the past few months from higher demand amid strikes at Ryanair and British Airways

However, total revenue per seat slipped by around 2.7 per cent across the year as airlines dropped prices amid heavy competition in the sector.

In the second half of the year, total revenue per seat only decreased by 0.8 per cent as the pilot strikes at its rivals took the heat off the competitive environment and demand for Easyjet flights picked up.



The airline's shares have taken off in recent weeks as it was pipped to pick up customers from collapsed Thomas Cook. But the stock slipped by more than 5 per cent to £11.11 on the back of today's update.

Easyjet said the demise of the world's oldest travel firm created 'difficult disruption' in the already turbulent sector.

It added that higher fuel costs, increased capacity and the weakness in the pound resulted in a 12 per cent jump in the headline costs for the full year, further denting already thin margins.

But it took cost-cutting measures to help mitigate the rising costs.

Chief executive Johan Lundgren said: 'Easyjet has continued to perform in line with expectations, despite challenging market conditions.

'As a result of our self-help initiatives and the increased demand due to disruption at British Airways and Ryanair, we anticipate achieving headline profit before tax for the full year 2019 of between £420 million and £430 million.

EasyJet said the demise of the world's oldest travel firm created 'difficult disruption' in the already turbulent sector

'We have continued to invest in operational resilience, with the programme successfully reducing the impact of disruption on our operations.'

Russ Mould from AJ Bell pointed to several reasons for the drop in the share price today, including high expectations and exposure to currency fluctuations.

'The market appears to have already been expecting Easyjet to issue a fairly bullish statement and so the actual news may not have been as impressive as some investors wanted,' he said.

'There was also a reminder in today's update of the extent to which the company is at the mercy of movements in fuel prices and foreign exchange, with a currency headwind of £14million.'

Mould added that the statement 'offers little reason for genuine excitement' with 'considerable uncertainty' around Brexit still hanging over the airline.
